page.title: 08King's School - History.
page.content: The {King's School}is an independent foundation and is predominantly a boarding school. It was founded in 1519 by Richard Fitzjames, Chief Justice of England, and John Edmunds, D.D., Chancellor of St. Paul's. On the Dissolution of the Monasteries in 1538, the school lands lapsed to the crown. However, in response to a petition, King Edward VI restored the endowment on 1 May 1550, and allowed a crown to be incorporated into the School crest, which also depicts the Dolphin, taken from the crest of the Fitzjames family. This century, there has been an expansion in all departments of school life, notably the founding of three new boarding houses. Within the last fifteen years, a number of new buildings have been constructed.
